\sphinxstepscope


\chapter{Actio Python Utils}
\label{\detokenize{readme:actio-python-utils}}\label{\detokenize{readme::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Various Python utility functions mostly about \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{argparse}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{logging}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{psycopg2}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pyspark}}.
Can be installed via \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pip}} e.g. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pip install git+ssh://git@github.com/ActioBio/actio\_python\_utils.git}}.


\section{Features}
\label{\detokenize{readme:features}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
TODO

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstepscope


\chapter{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{installation:installation}}\label{\detokenize{installation::doc}}

\section{Stable release}
\label{\detokenize{installation:stable-release}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To install Actio Python Utils, run this command in your terminal:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is the preferred method to install Actio Python Utils, as it will always install the most recent stable release.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you don’t have \sphinxhref{https://pip.pypa.io}{pip} installed, this \sphinxhref{http://docs.python-guide.org/en/latest/starting/installation/}{Python installation guide} can guide
you through the process.


\section{From sources}
\label{\detokenize{installation:from-sources}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The sources for Actio Python Utils can be downloaded from the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/brcopeland/actio\_python\_utils}{Github repo}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can either clone the public repository:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }git\PYG{+w}{ }clone\PYG{+w}{ }git://github.com/brcopeland/actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Or download the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/brcopeland/actio\_python\_utils/tarball/master}{tarball}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }curl\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}OJL\PYG{+w}{ }https://github.com/brcopeland/actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils/tarball/master
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Once you have a copy of the source, you can install it with:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }python\PYG{+w}{ }setup.py\PYG{+w}{ }install
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstepscope


\chapter{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{usage:usage}}\label{\detokenize{usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To use Actio Python Utils in a project:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To connect to the DB use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions.DBConnection}} class:
\index{DBConnection() (in module actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions)@\spxentry{DBConnection()}\spxextra{in module actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{usage:actio_python_utils.database_functions.DBConnection}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{DBConnection}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{service: str | None = None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{db\_args: \textasciitilde{}collections.abc.Mapping{[}str}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{\textasciitilde{}typing.Any{]} | None = None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{log\_name: str = \textquotesingle{}sql\_debug\textquotesingle{}}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{commit: bool = False}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{cursor\_factory: \textasciitilde{}psycopg2.extensions.cursor = \textless{}class \textquotesingle{}actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions.LoggingCursor\textquotesingle{}\textgreater{}}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ None}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Creates a psycopg2 database connection with the specified parameters and
acts as a context manager.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{service}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{None}}) \textendash{} The PostgreSQL service to connect to, defaults to None

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{db\_args}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Mapping}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{None}}) \textendash{} A mapping of database connection arguments, defaults to None

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{log\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The name to give the logger, defaults to
cfg{[}“logging”{]}{[}“names”{]}{[}“db”{]}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{commit}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Commit the transaction upon closing the connection if no
errors were encountered, defaults to False

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{psycopg2.cursor\_factory}} \textendash{} The class of cursor to use for the
connection by default (used for service/\$DB\_CONNECTION\_STRING, defaults
to LoggingCursor

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ValueError}} \textendash{} If service and db\_args are specified

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions}
\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.database_functions:module-actio_python_utils.database_functions}}\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.database_functions:actio-python-utils-database-functions}}\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.database_functions::doc}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions@\spxentry{actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions}}\index{actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions@\spxentry{actio\_python\_utils.database\_functions}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Database\sphinxhyphen{}related functionality.
\subsubsection*{Functions}


\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart
\sphinxthistablewithglobalstyle
\sphinxthistablewithnovlinesstyle
\centering
\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}[t]{\X{1}{2}\X{1}{2}}
\sphinxtoprule
\sphinxtableatstartofbodyhook
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{connect\_to\_db}}({[}service, db\_args{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Return a connection to the specified PostgreSQL database
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_db\_args}}({[}service, db\_args, logger, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns a dict of arguments to log in with psycopg2. Resolution order for connecting to a database is as follows:     1a. service, referring to a PostgreSQL service name, normally defined in         \textasciitilde{}/.pg\_service.conf     1b. db\_args, arbitrary dictionary of arguments     2. Environment variable DB\_CONNECTION\_STRING with format         postgres://your\_user:your\_password@your\_host:your\_port/your\_database     3. Environment variable PGSERVICE, referring to a PostgreSQL service         name     4. cfg{[}"db"{]}, which should resolve to a dictionary of arguments.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_pg\_config}}({[}service, service\_fn, pgpass\_fn{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Locates the PostgreSQL login credentials given a service name Uses service = \$PGSERVICE or cfg{[}"db"{]}{[}"service"{]} if not specified.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{replace\_dict\_values\_with\_global\_definition}}(mapping)
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Replaces values in the mapping with those in global\_mapping when the value is a str and it is a key in the global mapping
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{savepoint}}(cur{[}, savepoint{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Creates a context manager to create a savepoint upon entering, rollback if an error occurs, and release upon exiting
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{savepoint\_wrapper}}(method)
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Wraps a psycopg2 cursor\textquotesingle{}s method to use a savepoint
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{split\_schema\_from\_table}}(table{[}, default\_schema{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Split a possibly schema qualified table name into its schema and table names
\\
\sphinxbottomrule
\end{tabulary}
\sphinxtableafterendhook\par
\sphinxattableend\end{savenotes}

\subsection{actio\_python\_utils.logging\_functions}
\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.logging_functions:module-actio_python_utils.logging_functions}}\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.logging_functions:actio-python-utils-logging-functions}}\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.logging_functions::doc}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!actio\_python\_utils.logging\_functions@\spxentry{actio\_python\_utils.logging\_functions}}\index{actio\_python\_utils.logging\_functions@\spxentry{actio\_python\_utils.logging\_functions}!module@\spxentry{module}}

\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart

\sphinxtableatstartofbodyhook
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{LazyLogger}}(name{[}, level{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Wraps a Logger to accept either a message or a function to evaluate to produce the desired message.
\\
\sphinxbottomrule
\end{tabulary}
\sphinxtableafterendhook\par
\sphinxattableend\end{savenotes}

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{actio\_python\_utils.spark\_functions}
\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.spark_functions:module-actio_python_utils.spark_functions}}\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.spark_functions:actio-python-utils-spark-functions}}\label{\detokenize{_autosummary/actio_python_utils.spark_functions::doc}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!actio\_python\_utils.spark\_functions@\spxentry{actio\_python\_utils.spark\_functions}}\index{actio\_python\_utils.spark\_functions@\spxentry{actio\_python\_utils.spark\_functions}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Spark\sphinxhyphen{}related functionality.
\subsubsection*{Functions}


\begin{savenotes}\sphinxattablestart
\sphinxthistablewithglobalstyle
\sphinxthistablewithnovlinesstyle
\centering
\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}[t]{\X{1}{2}\X{1}{2}}
\sphinxtoprule
\sphinxtableatstartofbodyhook
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{convert\_chromosome}}(self, current\_column\_name)
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Return a PySpark dataframe with current\_column\_name (containing human chromosomes) with a new column, new\_column\_name (defaulting to overwriting the original), with the chromosome cast as an integer.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{convert\_dicts\_to\_dataframe}}(self{[}, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Converts either a list of dicts (dict\_list) or a function that returns an iterator of dicts (iter\_func) to a PySpark dataframe
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{count\_columns\_with\_string}}(self{[}, string{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Return a PySpark dataframe with the number of times a given string occurs in each string column in a dataframe
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{count\_distinct\_values}}(self{[}, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Return a new PySpark dataframe with the number of distinct values in each column.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{count\_nulls}}(self)
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Return a PySpark dataframe with the number of null values in each column of a dataframe
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{load\_dataframe}}(self, path{[}, format, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Load and return the specified data source using PySpark
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{load\_db\_to\_dataframe}}(self{[}, pgpass\_record, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Return a PySpark dataframe from either a relation or query
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{load\_excel\_to\_dataframe}}(self, xl\_fn{[}, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Load and return the specified Excel spreadsheet with PySpark
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar

&
\sphinxAtStartPar

\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{serialize\_array\_field}}(self, column, ...{[}, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Serializes an ArrayType field for output.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{serialize\_bool\_field}}(self, column, new\_column)
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Serializes a BooleanType field for output.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{serialize\_field}}(self, column{[}, new\_column, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Operates on a PySpark dataframe and converts any field of either atoms or structs, or any array of either of those (but not nested) to the properly formatted string for postgresql TEXT loading format and assigns it the column name new\_column.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{serialize\_string\_field}}(self, column, new\_column)
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Serializes a StringType field for output.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{serialize\_struct\_field}}(self, column, ...{[}, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Serializes a StructType field for output.
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{setup\_spark}}({[}cores, memory, use\_db, ...{]})
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Configures and creates a PySpark session according to the supplied arguments
\\
\sphinxhline
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{split\_dataframe\_to\_csv\_by\_column\_value}}(self, ...)
&
\sphinxAtStartPar
Split a dataframe with PySpark to a set of gzipped CSVs, e.g. if a dataframe has data: col1,col2,col3 1,1,1 1,2,3 2,1,1.
\\
\sphinxbottomrule
\end{tabulary}

\sphinxstepscope


\chapter{Contributing}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:contributing}}\label{\detokenize{contributing::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit
helps, and credit will always be given.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can contribute in many ways:


\section{Types of Contributions}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:types-of-contributions}}

\subsection{Report Bugs}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:report-bugs}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Report bugs at \sphinxurl{https://github.com/ActioBio/actio\_python\_utils/issues}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you are reporting a bug, please include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Your operating system name and version.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Fix Bugs}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:fix-bugs}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with “bug” and “help
wanted” is open to whoever wants to implement it.


\subsection{Implement Features}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:implement-features}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with “enhancement”
and “help wanted” is open to whoever wants to implement it.


\subsection{Write Documentation}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:write-documentation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Actio Python Utils could always use more documentation, whether as part of the
official Actio Python Utils docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts,
articles, and such.


\subsection{Submit Feedback}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:submit-feedback}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at \sphinxurl{https://github.com/ActioBio/actio\_python\_utils/issues}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you are proposing a feature:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Explain in detail how it would work.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Remember that this is a volunteer\sphinxhyphen{}driven project, and that contributions
are welcome :)

\end{itemize}


\section{Get Started!}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:get-started}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Ready to contribute? Here’s how to set up \sphinxtitleref{actio\_python\_utils} for local development.
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fork the \sphinxtitleref{actio\_python\_utils} repo on GitHub.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone your fork locally:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }git\PYG{+w}{ }clone\PYG{+w}{ }git@github.com:your\PYGZus{}name\PYGZus{}here/actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils.git
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install your local copy into a virtualenv. Assuming you have virtualenvwrapper installed, this is how you set up your fork for local development:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }mkvirtualenv\PYG{+w}{ }actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nb}{cd}\PYG{+w}{ }actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils/
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }python\PYG{+w}{ }setup.py\PYG{+w}{ }develop
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Create a branch for local development:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }git\PYG{+w}{ }checkout\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}b\PYG{+w}{ }name\PYGZhy{}of\PYGZhy{}your\PYGZhy{}bugfix\PYGZhy{}or\PYGZhy{}feature
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Now you can make your changes locally.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
When you’re done making changes, check that your changes pass flake8 and the
tests, including testing other Python versions with tox:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }flake8\PYG{+w}{ }actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils\PYG{+w}{ }tests
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }python\PYG{+w}{ }setup.py\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nb}{test}\PYG{+w}{ }or\PYG{+w}{ }pytest
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }tox
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To get flake8 and tox, just pip install them into your virtualenv.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }git\PYG{+w}{ }add\PYG{+w}{ }.
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }git\PYG{+w}{ }commit\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}m\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Your detailed description of your changes.\PYGZdq{}}
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }git\PYG{+w}{ }push\PYG{+w}{ }origin\PYG{+w}{ }name\PYGZhy{}of\PYGZhy{}your\PYGZhy{}bugfix\PYGZhy{}or\PYGZhy{}feature
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

\end{enumerate}


\section{Pull Request Guidelines}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:pull-request-guidelines}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The pull request should include tests.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put
your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the
feature to the list in README.rst.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The pull request should work for Python 3.5, 3.6, 3.7 and 3.8, and for PyPy. Check
\sphinxurl{https://travis-ci.com/ActioBio/actio\_python\_utils/pull\_requests}
and make sure that the tests pass for all supported Python versions.

\end{enumerate}


\section{Tips}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:tips}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To run a subset of tests:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }python\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}m\PYG{+w}{ }unittest\PYG{+w}{ }tests.test\PYGZus{}actio\PYGZus{}python\PYGZus{}utils
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Deploying}
\label{\detokenize{contributing:deploying}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A reminder for the maintainers on how to deploy.
Make sure all your changes are committed (including an entry in HISTORY.rst).
Then run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }bump2version\PYG{+w}{ }patch\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} possible: major / minor / patch}
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }git\PYG{+w}{ }push
\PYGZdl{}\PYG{+w}{ }git\PYG{+w}{ }push\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}tags
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Travis will then deploy to PyPI if tests pass.

\sphinxstepscope
